title: Allergic Reaction in Children
summary: Managing allergic reactions in children from mild symptoms to severe anaphylaxis. Quick action with antihistamines or epinephrine can be life-saving.

steps.title: Identify Reaction Severity
steps.description: Mild: hives, itching, sneezing. Moderate: widespread rash, mild swelling, vomiting. Severe (anaphylaxis): difficulty breathing, throat/tongue swelling, wheezing, rapid pulse. For severe, use EpiPen immediately.

steps.title: For Severe Reactions - Use EpiPen
steps.description: Give epinephrine auto-injector immediately for severe symptoms. Remove cap, press firmly into outer thigh, hold 10 seconds. Call 911 even if child improves. Give through clothing if needed.

steps.title: For Mild-Moderate - Give Antihistamine
steps.description: Give age-appropriate dose of antihistamine (Benadryl). Liquid works faster than tablets. Follow package dosing. Remove allergen source. Apply cool compresses to itchy areas. Monitor for worsening.

steps.title: Monitor and Comfort Child
steps.description: Keep child calm - anxiety worsens symptoms. Remove or avoid allergen. Loosen tight clothing. If wheezing, let child sit upright. Watch for symptom progression. Note time of exposure and symptoms.

steps.title: Follow-Up Care
steps.description: Even mild reactions need medical follow-up to identify allergen. Severe reactions require ER visit even if resolved. Get allergy testing. Obtain EpiPen prescription if needed. Create allergy action plan.

warnings: Reactions can worsen quickly - monitor continuously
Second wave of symptoms can occur hours later
Never leave allergic child alone during reaction
whenToSeekHelp: Call 911 for any breathing difficulty or throat swelling
Use EpiPen and call 911 for known severe allergies
See doctor same day for first-time reactions
preventionTips: Teach child not to share food
